# CRITICAL AI DEVELOPMENT GUIDELINES FOR COMSERV

## üöÄ By improving AI development practices, we can ensure a more efficient, consistent, and maintainable codebase for the Comserv project. This document outlines the key guidelines and best practices for AI-assisted development within the Comserv2 framework.
     - by keeping this file up-to-date, we can ensure that AI development remains aligned with the project's goals and standards.

## üö® DEVELOPMENT WORKFLOW CONSTRAINTS

### Prompt Limitations & AI Thread Management
- **MAXIMUM 3-4 PROMPTS** per task - AI consistency degrades after this point
- **PROMPT COUNTING**: User prompts count as 1 each,
- **MANDATORY PROMPT TRACKING**: AI MUST count user prompts and announce count in each response
- **ZENCODER LIMIT WARNINGS**: Zencoder is configured to warn when approaching context limits
  - **WARNING PROTOCOL**: When zencoder warns about approaching limits:
    - **DO NOT RESTART** the chat session
    - **CONTINUE FROM CURRENT POINT** - maintain context and progress
    - **NOTE**: Every code execution/tool use adds to the token count
    - **STRATEGY**: Minimize unnecessary tool calls when near limits
    - **FOCUS**: Complete current task efficiently without expanding scope
- **THREAD DEGRADATION SIGNS**: 
  - AI starts making assumptions about unseen code
  - AI creates unnecessary test files instead of direct fixes
  - AI loses focus on the specific problem
  - AI starts "hallucinating" about file contents or structures
    - User defines when a that is done.
- **CRITICAL 4TH PROMPT PROTOCOL**: On the 4th user prompt, AI MUST:
  1. **UPDATE THIS GUIDELINES FILE** with current task context and lessons learned
  2. **PROVIDE HANDOFF INFORMATION** for next chat session:
     - Exact problem statement
     - Files already modified
     - Specific issue remaining
     - What NOT to do (avoid previous mistakes)
     - Current task status and next steps
    - in a text box for easy copy-paste
    - remember to remind the AI to read this file at the start of the next chat
- **COMPLETION PROTOCOL**: 
  - **NEVER mark tasks as COMPLETED** until user explicitly confirms the fix works
  - **ALWAYS mark as IN PROGRESS** until user verification
  - **USER CONFIRMATION REQUIRED** before changing status from ONGOING to COMPLETED
- **GUIDELINES UPDATE REQUIREMENT**: Always update the "CURRENT TASK CONTEXT" section with:
  - Current problem being solved
  - Progress made
  - Files modified
  - Issues encountered
  - Next steps needed
    - When updating this file remove all the Completed tasks

### Testing Constraints
- **NO EXTERNAL TEST FILES** - test within application only
- **NO STANDALONE SCRIPTS** - Catalyst app has auto-restart on code changes
- **STANDALONE SCRIPTS for testing functions** - maybe used but must be removed after testing
- **FOCUS ON DIRECT FIXES** - Don't waste prompts on analysis, fix the code directly

### Application Testing Protocol
- Catalyst development server auto-restarts on file changes
- Local test scripts often pass but application tests fail
- **ALWAYS TEST WITHIN THE APPLICATION CONTEXT**
- Never attempt to run development server in chat (will always fail)

## üìÅ FILE STRUCTURE & NAMING STANDARDS

### Documentation System Architecture
- **PURE DIRECTORY-BASED SYSTEM** - No JSON config files to maintain
- **Directory structure determines categorization** automatically
- **File placement determines access permissions** and visibility
- **Self-organizing** - new files automatically indexed based on location

### Directory Structure Standards
```
/Documentation/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ changelog/          # System changes and updates (admin, developer)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ roles/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ normal/        # End-user documentation (normal, editor, admin, developer)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ admin/         # Administrator guides (admin, developer)
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ developer/     # Technical documentation (developer only)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sites/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {site_name}/   # Site-specific documentation
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ modules/           # System module documentation (admin, developer)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ controllers/       # Controller documentation (admin, developer)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ models/           # Model documentation (admin, developer)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tutorials/        # Step-by-step guides (all roles)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ proxmox/          # Proxmox documentation (admin only)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ [root files]      # General documentation (all roles)
```

### Template Files (.tt)
- **ALL DOCUMENTATION** must be .tt files (not .md)
- Follow existing naming conventions exactly
- **MANDATORY PageVersion headers**: `[% PageVersion = 'Comserv/root/Documentation/path/file.tt,v 0.01 YYYY/MM/DD author Exp author ' %]`
- **ALWAYS update PageVersion path** when moving files
- Include debug mode check: `[% IF c.session.debug_mode == 1 %]`

### CSS Management
- **NO INLINE CSS ALLOWED** - causes inconsistent styling unless to override existing styles for a very good reason
- All CSS goes in theme system: `/static/css/themes/`
- Use existing CSS variables and classes or modify to be theme-compliant
- Follow theme system patterns from existing files

### Controller Standards
- Use `log_with_details` method for all logging
- Follow existing route naming patterns
- Maintain consistency with existing controller structure

## üé® THEME SYSTEM COMPLIANCE

### CSS Variables (use existing)
```css
--primary-color, --secondary-color, --success-color, --danger-color
--warning-color, --text-color, --bg-color, --card-bg, --border-color
```

### Common Classes (reuse existing)
```css
.feature-card, .admin-card, .feature-grid, .admin-grid
.btn, .btn-primary, .btn-secondary, .search-input, .search-button
```

## üîß KNOWN ISSUES TO AVOID

### Documentation Controller
- Filename: `Documentation.pm` (correct spelling)
- Package: `Comserv::Controller::Documentation`
- Routes work: `/Documentation/` (capital D)

### Template Integration
- Use existing template includes and structure
- Check for missing template dependencies
- Follow existing INCLUDE patterns

## ‚úÖ DOCUMENTATION SYSTEM - FULLY FUNCTIONAL

### Role-Based Documentation Access
The documentation system now supports role-based content delivery:

**USER ROLES**:
- **normal** - Basic users, access to user guides and tutorials
- **editor** - Content editors, access to user guides and some admin content
- **admin** - System administrators, access to admin guides and system management
- **developer** - Technical staff, access to all documentation including technical details

**DOCUMENTATION CATEGORIES**:
- **user_guides** - End-user documentation (normal, editor, admin, developer)
- **admin_guides** - Administrative documentation (admin, developer)
- **developer_guides** - Technical documentation (developer only)
- **tutorials** - Step-by-step guides (all roles)
- **modules** - System module documentation (admin, developer)
- **site_specific** - Site-specific content (all roles, filtered by site)

**AI DOCUMENTATION DELIVERY GUIDELINES**:
When users request documentation, determine their role and deliver appropriate content:
1. **Ask for user role** if not specified: "What is your role? (normal user, admin, developer)"
2. **Provide role-appropriate documentation** from `/Documentation/roles/{role}/`
3. **Reference comprehensive docs** for developers: `/Documentation/{module}.tt`
4. **Use documentation config** to determine access permissions

## üìù DEVELOPMENT BEST PRACTICES

### AI Thread Management
- **IMMEDIATE ACTION**: Don't spend prompts on analysis - start fixing immediately
- **SINGLE FOCUS**: Fix one specific issue per thread, don't expand scope
- **AVOID RABBIT HOLES**: Don't create test scripts, debug tools, or analysis files
- **DIRECT EDITS ONLY**: Modify the actual application files that need fixing
- **FINAL PROMPT WORKFLOW**: On successful completion:
  1. Clean up AI_DEVELOPMENT_GUIDELINES (remove completed tasks)
  2. Create changelog entry documenting changes
  3. **RETURN COMMIT MESSAGE IN CHAT BOX** - Never create COMMIT_MESSAGE.txt files (they get deleted)
  4. **FOLLOW .TT GUIDELINES** - All files must be proper .tt template files with PageVersion headers
  5. Add any discovered issues to future repair queue

### Code Practices
- **Ask permission** before modifying existing files
- **Use existing patterns** - don't reinvent styling/structure
- **CHECK FOR EXISTING FUNCTIONALITY FIRST** - Always search for existing solutions before creating new ones
- **SIMPLE FIXES FIRST** - Change links/routes before creating new files or complex solutions
- **Check dependencies** - ensure required modules/plugins exist
- **Test incrementally** - small changes, test each step
- **Follow naming conventions** - match existing file patterns exactly

### Common AI Thread Failures
1. **Over-Analysis**: Spending prompts examining code instead of fixing
2. **Test File Creation**: Making external scripts instead of direct fixes
3. **Scope Creep**: Expanding beyond the original problem
4. **Path Confusion**: Making assumptions about file locations
5. **Dependency Rabbit Holes**: Trying to install/fix dependencies instead of core issue
6. **DUPLICATE FUNCTIONALITY**: Creating new files/methods instead of using existing ones
7. **COMPLEX SOLUTIONS**: Building complicated fixes when simple link changes would work

### Issue Discovery Protocol
When finding issues outside current task scope:
1. **Document in Issue Queue**: Add to "Issue Queue for Future Repair" section
2. **Include Context**: Location, impact level, and notes for future developer
3. **Don't Fix Immediately**: Stay focused on current task unless critical
4. **Format**: Use consistent format for easy parsing by future AI threads

<h2>Core Principles</h2>



<ol><li>**Follow Existing Patterns**: Always examine and follow existing code patterns before creating new ones.</li></ol>

<ol><li>**Reuse Existing Code**: Identify and reuse existing modules, utilities, and templates.</li></ol>

<ol><li>**Respect Directory Structure**: Place new files in the appropriate existing directories.</li></ol>

<ol><li>**Maintain Naming Conventions**: Follow established naming patterns for files, classes, and methods.</li></ol>

<ol><li>**Request Permission for Structural Changes**: Obtain explicit permission before creating new directories or changing established patterns.</li></ol>



<h2>Session Workflow (5-10 Prompts)</h2>



Given the limited number of interactions in each session (5-10 prompts), follow this workflow:



<ol><li>**Read Documentation & Code** (1-2 prompts)</li></ol>

   - Examine relevant documentation in <code>/Comserv/root/Documentation/</code>

   - Review existing code patterns in related modules

   - Identify reusable components



<ol><li>**Propose Solution** (1 prompt)</li></ol>

   - Outline approach based on existing patterns

   - Identify files to modify

   - Highlight any reused components



<ol><li>**Implement Solution** (2-3 prompts)</li></ol>

   - Make minimal necessary changes

   - Follow existing code style and patterns

   - Document code with appropriate comments



<ol><li>**Test & Debug** (1-2 prompts)</li></ol>

   - Verify functionality

   - Address any issues



<ol><li>**Update Documentation** (1 prompt)</li></ol>

   - Update relevant documentation files

   - Create commit message



<h2>File Storage Guidelines</h2>



<h3>Database vs. JSON Storage</h3>



<ol><li>**Database Storage**:</li></ol>

   - Use for persistent data requiring complex queries

   - Follow existing database models in <code>Comserv/lib/Comserv/Model/</code>

   - Access via the configured database connections in <code>db_config.json</code>



<ol><li>**JSON File Storage**:</li></ol>

   - Appropriate for configuration data and simple data models

   - Use for prototyping before implementing database storage

   - Store in <code>Comserv/config/</code> directory with descriptive filenames

   - Follow the pattern in <code>NetworkMap.pm</code> for loading/saving JSON data



<h2>Directory Structure Guidelines</h2>



<ol><li>**Controllers**: <code>/Comserv/lib/Comserv/Controller/</code></li></ol>

   - One controller per functional area

   - Follow RESTful action naming when possible



<ol><li>**Models**: <code>/Comserv/lib/Comserv/Model/</code></li></ol>

   - Database models in appropriate subdirectories

   - Result classes for database tables



<ol><li>**Utilities**: <code>/Comserv/lib/Comserv/Util/</code></li></ol>

   - Reusable helper functions

   - Standalone functionality



<ol><li>**Templates**: <code>/Comserv/root/[Module]/</code></li></ol>

   - Template files (.tt) for each module

   - Follow existing template patterns



<ol><li>**Documentation**: <code>/Comserv/root/Documentation/</code></li></ol>

   - Organized by category/role

   - Use markdown format



<h2>Template System Guidelines</h2>



<ol><li>**Use Template Toolkit (.tt) files**</li></ol>

   - Follow patterns in existing templates

   - Use proper includes and template hierarchy



<ol><li>**Template Variables**</li></ol>

   - Access session data via <code>c.session</code>

   - Controller data via <code>c.stash</code>

   - Use consistent variable naming



<ol><li>**Error Handling**</li></ol>

   - Use TRY/CATCH blocks for potentially problematic includes

   - Provide fallback content



<h2>Commit Message Format</h2>



<code></code>`

[Module] Brief description of changes



<ul><li>Detailed bullet point of change 1</li></ul>

<ul><li>Detailed bullet point of change 2</li></ul>



Related files:

<ul><li>path/to/modified/file1.pm</li></ul>

<ul><li>path/to/modified/file2.tt</li></ul>



Documentation updates:

<ul><li>Updated path/to/documentation.md</li></ul>

<code></code>`



<h2>Example: Adding a Feature to NetworkMap</h2>



<h3>Good Approach:</h3>

<ol><li>Examine existing <code>NetworkMap.pm</code> utility and controller</li></ol>

<ol><li>Reuse the JSON storage pattern</li></ol>

<ol><li>Add new methods to existing classes</li></ol>

<ol><li>Update existing templates</li></ol>

<ol><li>Document in the appropriate documentation files</li></ol>



<h3>Avoid:</h3>

<ol><li>Creating new directories without clear need</li></ol>

<ol><li>Implementing different storage mechanisms</li></ol>

<ol><li>Duplicating existing functionality</li></ol>

<ol><li>Using different naming conventions</li></ol>

<ol><li>Creating new templates when existing ones can be modified</li></ol>



<h2>Final Checklist</h2>



Before submitting changes, verify:



<ul><li>[ ] Code follows existing patterns and conventions</li></ul>

<ul><li>[ ] No unnecessary new files or directories created</li></ul>

<ul><li>[ ] Existing code reused where appropriate</li></ul>

<ul><li>[ ] Documentation updated</li></ul>

<ul><li>[ ] Commit message prepared according to format</li></ul>

</div>

I understand the guidelines now. Let me examine the actual button color issue on the todo day page. The buttons are still showing blue text instead of theme colors despite the CSS specificity fix.

Good! I can see that `.btn` styles ARE in base-containers.css. Let me examine the actual button styles:

Perfect! I can see the issue now. The buttons are using classes like:
- `btn btn-secondary` 
- `btn btn-success`
- `btn btn-warning btn-sm`
- `btn btn-info btn-sm`

But looking at the CSS, I see that the `!important` declarations might not be enough to override the link color. Let me check what the actual link color is set to in the base.css:

Found it! The issue is in base.css line 52: `color: var(--link-color);` and the `--link-color: #0000FF;` (blue). 

Let me check the exact CSS rule that's causing the problem:

The problem is clear now. The `a { color: var(--link-color); }` rule in base.css is overriding the button colors because it has the same specificity as `a.btn` but comes later in the CSS cascade.

Looking at the base-containers.css, I need to check if the button color overrides are comprehensive enough. Let me look at more button styles:

I can see the button styles are comprehensive and use `!important`. However, the issue might be that the CSS loading order is wrong, or there's still a specificity issue. Let me check if there are any other CSS rules that might be interfering.

The real issue is likely that even with `!important`, the `a { color: var(--link-color); }` rule from base.css is still taking precedence because it's loaded after base-containers.css.

Let me check the CSS loading order in the include file:

The CSS loading order is correct: base.css ‚Üí base-containers.css ‚Üí theme.css ‚Üí site.css

The problem is that even though base-containers.css comes after base.css, the `a { color: var(--link-color); }` rule is still overriding the button colors because CSS specificity is the same and the `!important` on the color property in the button styles might not be working as expected.

Let me add more specific CSS rules to ensure the button colors override the link colors. I need to add higher specificity selectors:
Now I need to update all the other button style selectors to include the higher specificity `body[class*="theme-"] a.btn-*` selectors:
Now I need to update the btn-primary selectors:
Now I need to update btn-secondary:
Now I need to update btn-success:
Now btn-info:
Now btn-warning:

Perfect! Now I've added higher specificity CSS selectors (`body[class*="theme-"] a.btn-*`) to all button styles. This should override the `a { color: var(--link-color); }` rule from base.css.

The changes I made:

1. **Added Higher Specificity Selectors**: Added `body[class*="theme-"] a.btn-*` selectors to all button styles
2. **Comprehensive Coverage**: Updated all button types (btn, btn-primary, btn-secondary, btn-success, btn-info, btn-warning) and their hover states
3. **CSS Specificity Fix**: The `body[class*="theme-"] a.btn` selector has higher specificity than just `a` from base.css

**CURRENT STATUS**: ‚è≥ **IN PROGRESS** - CSS specificity fixes implemented, awaiting user testing verification

**FILES MODIFIED THIS PROMPT**:
- ‚úÖ `Comserv/root/static/css/themes/base-containers.css` - Added higher specificity selectors to override link colors

**EXPECTED RESULTS**:
- CSC: Button text should now use theme colors instead of blue (#0000FF)
- USBM: Button text should use green theme colors 
- All Sites: Buttons should respect theme colors instead of inheriting link colors

The CSS changes should now properly override the link color inheritance. Please test the todo day page to verify that button text colors now match the theme instead of showing blue.
